awd_titl_txt: Tripods+X:Res: Collaborative Research: Identification of Gene Regulatory Network Function from Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Molecular and cellular biology are at the forefront of our quest to understand life and improve human health. However, the details of how genes and signals interact in real time to produce cell behavior, are not well understood.  The problem is a lack of approaches that can integrate experimental data into models that describe the important behavior of the system, yet do not describe nonessential details, that would make it too cumbersome to compute in a reasonable time. This project will develop a new set of tools, that can predict the entire range of behaviors of a network of interdependent genes and do it so efficiently that behavior under the effect of a few mutations or behavior of alternative sets of genes can be readily explored. Furthermore, once such a description of behavior of a set of genes is available, it will be shared and used by other scientists. Continuous build-up of these results will rapidly increase their value for data science, cellular biology, and broader science. 
   					
Molecular and cellular biology have witnessed a huge leap forward since science has acquired the ability to sequence genomes. However, while genomes are relatively static, the phenotypes result from the interaction of many genes that are expressed dynamically in time. Furthermore, since phenotypes arise from complex transcriptional networks, where the interactions tend to be nonlinear, data-based models will play a key role in understanding and ultimately controlling these phenotypes. Current modeling techniques, motivated by physics, struggle to bridge a fundamental conflict between low resolution of biological measurements informing model parameter values and the fundamental fact that dynamical systems are sensitive to initial conditions and parameters. This project develops a novel mathematical framework that provides a quantitative description of global dynamics that are compatible with coarse, noisy biological measurements. Combined with computationally efficient algorithms for the construction of databases that capture biologically relevant dynamics of a network, it can become the basis for shared science in the space of gene networks. These tools will be used to construct and validate network models from experimental data, interrogate dynamic behavior of a given network, and compare dynamics summaries across networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cellular biology investigates how cells function when they are healthy and when they are damaged. Cells adjust their behavior by changing their internal programs of gene expression, and these responses are a result of networks of gene and protein nteractions. While ability to sequence genomes allows us to identify the genes, our ability to detect the interactions between genes and then understand how a complicated network of interaction behaves under stress is still very limited.

The first goal  of our project was to develop mathematical and computational techniques that would construct networks of interactions  from experimental data. Further, once the network is known, the second goal was to develop a method that would describe behavior of such a network in all circumstances. 

To address the first goal we developed a three part pipeline of computational tools, that takes as an input a set of time series of experimental data that describe the expression level of a set of genes over time. The output of the pipeline is a set of networks describing interactions between these genes that are most likely responsible for the observed behavior.  The first part of the three part pipeline scans the time series and ranks them based on the likelihood that they are affected by other genes and thus are not static. The second part of the pipeline looks at all pairs of  highly ranked genes from part one and ranks them based on the likelihood that one of them affects the other. Finally, in the third step, the highly ranked pairs are combined to networks. There are millions of such networks that can be constructed and we use our newly developed methodology to quickly scan them for their ability to show dynamic behavior that is observed experimentaly. This behavior could, for instance, be a periodic behavior that supports a cell cycle. Those networks that readily show observed dynamics are ranked high. This approach offers guidance to experimentalists to focus their experiments in such a way that would resolve in the most direct way the remaining ambiguity which of the networks represent the true molecular interactions. 

The methodology described in the last step of the pipeline aims to answer an important problem in cellular network modeling. Once we understand the network of interactions, to actually precisely predict how the network behaves one needs to precisely quantify the strength and duration of these interactions. However, it is almost impossible to conduct sufficient number of precise experiments to determine these numbers. Our method describes the interactions in such a way that even without the precise numbers, we can compute all possible behaviors across all of their possible values. By necessity, these methods are approximate but are so computationally efficient that they can compute all dynamics of a network in a few seconds, allowing such computations to be conducted across thousands and millions of networks.

This approach can serve as a first tool for a molecular biologist  to use when investigating a novel cellular mechanism. It allows him/her to discard some potential network models, while focusing on those that are able to support the observed  cellular function.

This methodology belongs to a class of Data Science methods that are playing increasing role in molecular and cellualar biology. We  hope that this methodolgy will have an impact on rational development of new pharmaceutical agents by designing them to fit a unique  role in a particular network of cellular interactions.
